Award.AwardTitle: Women in Cognitive Science: Professional development and building networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Four workshops are designed for women in cognitive science, especially women in the early stages of their academic career. The focus will be on the "imposter phenomenon," the internal emotional experience of not being qualified, both intellectually and professionally, despite objective evidence indicating the opposite. Research suggests that this phenomenon is widespread but is experienced more often by women than by men. Its well-documented aversive effects can be a significant psychological barrier to seeking a career in science. The workshops focus on negotiation techniques to create opportunities and optimize mechanisms to sustain research productivity. A second focus is on predoctoral, postdoctoral, and early career grant application writing. The workshops are to be held in conjunction with four major scientific meetings in Psychology, across a broad geographical area (the Cognitive Science Society, the Psychonomic Society, the Association for Psychological Science, and the Society for Mathematical Psychology). The workshops will take the form of a public forum with invited speaker-panelists to initiate discussion about best practices for the professional advancement of women in cognitive science at the individual and institutional level. By partnering with these established societies, the workshops will maximize the outreach potential to a group that continues to be underrepresented in senior academic positions in the cognitive sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scholarly achievements of women scientists have increased substantially in recent decades, but that increase is not generally echoed in traditional measures of recognition (including academic rank, administrative positions, research prizes). The goal of Women in Cognitive Science (WICS) is to improve the visibility of women scientists by fostering an environment that welcomes and nurtures young women scholars within Psychology and Cognitive Science that traditionally attract fewer women than men. WICS also aims to contribute to the professional development of scholars throughout their career and to facilitate creating a network that will provide contacts and connections to other women in science.

One of the most visible activities of WICS is the organization of panel discussions at conferences of professional societies. Typically, WICS invites around four speakers to give a presentation about a particular theme, followed by a discussion with the audience. During the one-year funding period, WICS has organized four panel discussions (and two webinars). WICS has organized a panel discussion at the Cognitive Science meeting in Berlin (2013), entitled "Professional advancement through real and virtual international collaboration". WICS has co-organized a panel discussion at the 2013 meeting of the Society for Mathematical Psychology in Potsdam "Networking and collaboration". At the annual meeting of the Psychonomic Society (November 14, 2013) as well as at the Association for Psychological Science (May 24, 2014), WICS has organized a webinar followed by a panel discussion. The theme of this WICS event was "Intellectual phony or successful academic? Overcoming the impostor syndrome". During this meeting, Dr. Valerie Young (author of the well-known book "The secret thoughts of successful women: Why capable people suffer from the impostor syndrome and how to thrive in spite of it") held a one-hour webinar, followed by a panel discussion. The webinar speaker had generously waived her speaker fee in exchange of purchasing 100 of her books which we distributed among people in the audience.

 The WICS webinars/panel discussions were well-attended (sometimes over 100 people participated), and postmeeting evaluations consistently demonstrate that participants greatly appreciate the meetings and praise its usefulness.

The grant also provided funding for travel awards and mentorship awards. The travel awards have been awarded to four junior women to provide networking opportunities and to create collaborations with colleagues in other labs. The funds for two mentorship awards have been awarded to mentors who have distinguished themselves as effective mentors and advisors, and who have demonstrated sustained and effective mentorship of female students. Their excellent mentorship qualities were honored during a special ceremony at the 2014 meeting of the Psychonomic Society, and their mentorship will serve as a model to other researchers.

WICS also maintains a website (http://womenincogsci.org/) and a Facebook page.  WICS-officers regularly post WICS activities, job announcements, and links to actual discussions on topics related to, for example, the position of women in science and gender equity.

During the duration of this grant, the WICS membership increased from 790 to 985 members.

 

WICS has a long-standing relationship with the Psychonomic Society, basically since its inception in 2001. WICS has also organized panel discussions at the bi-annual meetings of the European Society for Cognitive Psychology as of 2005 (these activities have not been funded through NSF). As of 2009, WICS has partnered with the Association for Psychological Science and the Cognitive Science Society and has organized panel discussions at their conferences.
